author: agizmo
body:
This was all tested on a server running Ubuntu 14.04. I have a group on the system called "sharing" that my user account and others are a member of to help facilitate sharing of files. Many files have their permissions set to `<different users>:sharing` on a 2nd hard drive on the server. If I use "rm" in Bash I can delete files that are setup with these permissions even if my user account is not the owner because I am a member of the same group that owns the file. If I go into Powershell and try to use "remove-item" to delete the same file I get an error message saying access was denied.

Steps to reproduce
------------------

Example 1: Bash Only
```bash
# group members
$ cat /etc/group | grep sharing
sharing:x:1001:,tony,plex
# create a test file. These commands were run in BASH.
$ echo "hello" >> test_del.txt
$ ls -la | grep test_del.txt
-rw-rw-r--  1 tony tony        6 Jan 15 10:45 test_del.txt
# change the ownership of the file
$ chown plex:sharing test_del.txt
$ ls -la | grep test_del.txt
-rw-rw-r--  1 plex sharing        6 Jan 15 10:45 test_del.txt
# using "rm" in bash can successfully delete the file
$ rm test_del.txt
```

Example 2: Try to delete the file using PowerShell
```bash
# recreate the test file and change ownership
$ echo "hello" >> test_del.txt
$ ls -la | grep test_del.txt
-rw-rw-r--  1 tony tony        6 Jan 15 10:45 test_del.txt
$ chown plex:sharing test_del.txt
$ ls -la | grep test_del.txt
-rw-rw-r--  1 plex sharing        6 Jan 15 10:45 test_del.txt
```
```powershell
# jump into PowerShell and try to delete the file
> remove-item ./test_del.txt
```

Example 3: Set the ownership to the current user and sharing group and delete the file
```bash
$ echo "hello" >> test_del.txt
$ ls -la | grep test_del.txt
-rw-rw-r--  1 tony tony        6 Jan 15 10:45 test_del.txt
$ chown tony:sharing test_del.txt
$ ls -la | grep test_del.txt
-rw-rw-r--  1 tony sharing        6 Jan 15 10:45 test_del.txt
```
```powershell
# PowerShell will be able to successfully delete the file with these ownership settings
> remove-item ./test_del.txt
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

"rm" in BASH is able to delete the file so PowerShell should be able to as well. 

Actual behavior
---------------

PowerShell returns the following error:
```powershell
> Remove-Item ./test_del.txt                                       
Remove-Item : You do not have sufficient access rights to perform this 
operation.
At line:1 char:1
+ Remove-Item ./test_del.txt
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : PermissionDenied: (/home/tony/test_del.txt:FileI 
   nfo) [Remove-Item], IOException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : RemoveFileSystemItemUnAuthorizedAccess,Microsoft 
   .PowerShell.Commands.RemoveItemCommand
```

Environment data
----------------

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable                                                  

Name                           Value                                           
----                           -----                                           
PSVersion                      6.0.0                                           
PSEdition                      Core                                            
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0                                          
OS                             Linux 4.4.0-109-generic #132~14.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Tue Jan 9 21:46:42 UTC 2018
Platform                       Unix                                            
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}                         
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3                                             
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1                                         
WSManStackVersion              3.0 
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @agizmo  Do you the issue with latest PowerShell 7.0 build?

comments.author: msftbot[bot]
comments.body: This issue has been marked as "Waiting on Author" and has not had any activity for **7 day**. It has been closed for housekeeping purposes.

title: Remove-Item fails when file ownership only matches current users group
